text: MTV's Kurt Loder reports from the Berlin Wall. We see fro the MTV news footage that massive crowds are assembling. EAST GERMAN SOLDIERS stand on the Wall, holding an MTV umbrella, an iconic symbol of the times.
We MOVE ON a reflection of Perceval on the television. Perceval leans in, shuts off the television and stands wi clear objective. Time to go.

The air is electric as West Germans carry hammers, chisel and pickaxes with purpose towards the Berlin wall. We see Perceval turn the corner into a dark alleyway near parked Saab 900 Turbo. Perceval sees a figure in the shad and slows.
Well, I suppose that’s it. We’ll be obsolete by morning. I’1l be back in London, and you... back to the party. We hear the faint sounds of HAMMERS STRIKING against concrete.

The simplicity of our struggle crumbles as that wall comes down. The lines on the map drawn by men who never faced the risk themselves will be harder to see. In the distance, the CROWDS’ CHEERS are heard.

A different world is approaching. More volatile. More corrupt. There will be no ideologies to protect us. Just the brutal and cold conscience of commerce. Perceval’s eyes follow a group of West Germans with hand tools moving towards the Wall.
Extortion... Whoever has the list in this new world has all power. Without it? Just a target. Perceval turns back to the wordless figure in the shadows
We played our hands. Hell, I’m just glad to see your face at this moment, as the ramparts of tyranny fall into the history books. Perceval smiles softly to himself as he looks towards the crowds.
Listen to them. In the faint light, we see the flash of gunmetal. We hear a GUNSHOT BARK out!

SUPER: “LONDON, NOVEMBER 11, 1989 - TWO DAYS LATER” A bathtub filled with ice cubes and freezing water. A wom appears from beneath the surface. This is LORRAINE BROUGHTON. Broughton’s body is athletic and strong but also patchwor bruises and cuts from the last ten days. She pulls a towe across her body, steps from the cold water and pours two fingers of Stoli into glass. Broughton looks down at the words “Hotel Moskva” on the label and then to the mirror. She CLICKS on the dial of shitty RADIO. We hear David Bow “Cat People Putting out Fire.” Broughton opens a vanity drawer. Next to the cosmetics i framed photo of her and a handsome man in front of the Bl Mosque in Istanbul. Broughton stares down at the photo fo moment, held by a memory and then reaches for a compact. Broughton covers her contusions with makeup and dresses i Navy crepe wool skirt suit from Chanel, heels and Jackie- sunglasses. Simple and sexy. As she opens a Kelly bag we see a Browning Hi-Power at re next to a pack of Woodbine cigarettes. Broughton doesn’t to chamber check the weapon. It’s always loaded, cocked, locked and awaiting her command. She pulls a cigarette from the pack, steps out of the bathroom, glances at the her empty bed and lights her Woodbine. Broughton walks out her apartment door. Bowie’s voice builds as we follow her out.
The morning is crisp. A double-decker bus drives past wit “Boycott Apartheid” painted on its side.
Just across the Westminster Bridge sits a limestone and g post-modern fortress. This is the British headquarters of MI6. Broughton walks through the busy streets and into th Century House.

Broughton moves through the lobby and towards a line of people waiting at the metal detectors. The SECURITY PERSO wave her straight through. She belongs here; she’s a bad Security walks her to a single elevator, inserts a key, a Broughton enters the elevator alone. The doors close.
There is only one button, and that is an arrow down. Broughton pushes the button and rides the elevator for so time.

As the doors open, she is meet by another two armed secur personnel who nod and wave her past them. Broughton walks down a long, top lit, Kubrickian 60s hal We see a remote video camera track her. No one else is do here, and the two security personnel are 100 yards away b now. Broughton stops at an unmarked door. We see another video camera lens focus on her, and the electronic DEAD BOLT CL the door open.

The “BIN” is a sterile ISO-FAC (Isolation Facility) for t debriefing of operatives returning to England. The room i sparse. All the walls are covered in 60s acoustic sound t save for a two-way mirror on one wall. MR. ERIC GRAY, mid-sixties and capable, sits with EMMETT KURZFELD of the CIA at wooden table. Broughton enters and slows as she sees Kurzfeld.
How was your flight?
Uncomfortable. Broughton takes a seat across from the two men. BROUGHTON (CONT’D) Sir, what is he doing here?
We thought it would be helpful to get Kurzfeld’s perspective. Gray leans back and sits next to Kurzfeld.

head_text.subj: OTHER SIDE OF THE TWO-WAY MIRROR

text: We see a older man, “C,” watching. His face is reflected the glass of the two-way mirror.
Given the scale of recent world events, C will not be joining us. Broughton looks straight into the two-way mirror and nods with the confidence that C is there.
Yes, of course.
Broughton looks at Gray and Kurzfeld.
Let’s begin, for the record. Gray reaches across to a Nagra III reel-to-reel recording unit that rests on the desk. Gray CLICKS the recording DI

Under formal direction of the Joint Intelligence Committee: The following will serve as first contact and operational archive for Her Majesty’s Military Intelligence Section 6. Recorded on the 11th of November 1989. The voices of record are as follows, Senior Directorate Officer Eric Gray, Senior Case Officer Emmett Kurzfeld of the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, and returning British Operational Officer Lorraine Broughton. Gray leans forward and begins the interview. GRAY (CONT’D) Tell us about Berlin. Were you there when Perceval was shot? Broughton calmly replies to Gray.
No. Broughton looks to the two-way mirror and then to Kurzfel Gray scribbles down a note in a folder stamped “Top Secre in front of him and looks up at Broughton.
Let’s start from the beginning, shall we? A GRAFFITI TITLE CARD SCRAWLS OUT: “THE COLDEST CITY”

SUPER: “LONDON, NOVEMBER 2, 1989 - NINE DAYS AGO” Hard rain. Broughton walks up the wide stairs of Century House. A handmade Fox umbrella shelters her from the weat  INT. CENTURY HOUSE - GRAY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS The office is classic British Empire. Framed conquest map hang on the walls. A Regent desk in dark wood and oxblood leather chairs. Gray and another man, the Chief of the Se Intelligence Service known only as "“C,” sit across from another.
Broughton speaks four languages, and her Russian is excellent. Cc What about her field craft and perishable skills?

She's an expert in Escape and Evasion, NATO and Warsaw Pact Weapons systems, and hand-to-hand combat. Cc Knowing the reds as I do, she'll need to use every damn one of them. There is a KNOCK on the office DOOR. Neither Gray or C st as Broughton enters the room.
Sorry to pull you in on short notice, Lorraine. You know C, of course. Broughton looks to the emotionless man who remains seated a straight-back chair.

Yes, of course. C motions towards a chair, and Broughton sits at the tabl and opens a pack of Woodbine cigarettes. BROUGHTON (CONT’D) Mind if I smoke, sir? Gray pulls a cadet lighter from his pocket, leans across desk and lights Broughton’s Woodbine. Broughton takes a d off of her cigarette and exhales.
I‘ll get straight to the point. How well do you know, James Gascione?
Enough to say hello... We did work together several years back in Istanbul. Gray and C share a quick look, trying to decipher if she lying to them.
As of yesterday morning Gascione was reported as incommunicado.

SUPER: “WEST BERLIN, NOVEMBER 1, 1989” 5 AM. Snow is falling. Most Berliners in the French, Brit and American sectors of this divided city are asleep. A dependable-looking middle-aged man runs down the empty street.(The same man from the photo in Broughton’s vanity This is JAMES GASCIONE.

Who was Gascione handling? Gascione’s shoes pound the pavement. His lungs burn. Each quick exhale leaves a ghostly trail behind him. Remember gradation of fear in Gascione’s eyes as he glances over h shoulder.

Gascione was running an agent codenamed Spyglass, a Stasi officer. Two ROUGH MEN chase after him through the snow. They are business. They are KGB. Gascione cuts through a backyard, hurdles several fences, vaults over a brick wall and lands. He checks over his shoulder again. Nothing. Maybe he lost them.

Spyglass had just delivered a list to Gascione. Gascione sprints towards the river and glances again just as... ... the ROAR of an ENGINE gets his attention. Gascione h his hands out on instinct, headlights blinding him until feels the front of a sedan SLAM into his legs just above knees. Gascione’s body is lifted and then violently pinned again parked car. Pain surges through his body as he looks down his mangled legs. The sedan reverses a few feet, and Gasc crumples facedown onto the snowy pavement. The two rough men slowly jog up to the scene as an averag looking man, YURI BAKHTIN emerges from the car and moves towards Gascione.
Look at me. Gascione’s eyes tilt upward at Bakhtin.

You... cossack... bastard! Bakhtin presses the barrel of a Makarov pistol onto Gascione’s forehead. The MAKAROV BARKS OUT, and Gasicone consumed by the white halo of a muzzle flash. Silence. Bakhtin grabs Gascione’s wrist and removes a classic “” C Bucherer ” wrist watch. Bakhtin nods towards the two roug men, who lift Gasicone’s lifeless body from the blood-soa snow and dump it into the river Spree.
Gascione is dead. INT. CENTURY HOUSE - GRAY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Broughton lowers her cigarette without a word.
The Jerries fished him out of the Spree River this morning. A West German coroner extracted a 9x18mm from the base of his skull.
Soviets. Gray sets down a black-and-white photo of an average-look MAN in a Soviet military uniform.
Our sources point to Yuri Bakhtin, a lead KGB officer who was ticketed out of Berlin on Aeroflot to Moscow.
You want me in Moscow? Cc Bakhtin never arrived in Moscow. Gray picks up the photo and scans the documents within a (Top Secret) folder stamped “UK eyes only.”
So either our man on the ground is wrong, or Bakhtin pulled a switch and is now lost to us. Broughton takes another drag from her cigarette.
Gascione was en route to where?
Our Head of Berlin operations when he was assassinated.
How sensitive is the list?

Spyglass claimed it was a complete inventory of the identities and locations of every active clandestine officer. Broughton lowers her cigarette as a thin ribbon of smoke curls up towards the low ceiling.
Is that even possible? Cc The real question must be: is it wise to hope it’s not possible instead of proving it is? There is a moment of silence in the room. A challenge has just been laid down.  10.
Everyone is hunting for it: the Yanks, the Frogs, us, and the Soviets for sure. Cc Tell her the rest of the good news.

Spyglass disclosed the list would expose a double agent by the name of “Satchel” within the allied intelligence network. Cc You find Satchel in this embarrassing mess and we'll hang him for treason. Broughton exhales smoke from her lungs and hardens to the truth of this knowledge. Cc (CONT'D) The list is the whole damn chessboard. Whoever controls it controls the Cold War.

Berlin is already on a short fuse. Hungary has dismantled hundreds of kilometers of the Iron Curtain since May. Last month, East Germans stormed the FRG’s embassies in Prague and Warsaw. They were given immunity and sent to West Germany. Cc Gorbachev’s glasnost nonsense has his people hopeful, and there is nothing worse than a hopeful enemy.
The Wall won’t last much longer. David thinks it might even fall before Christmas.
David, sir?
David Perceval is our number one in Berlin. We are sending you to link up with him.  11.
I’ve never been to Berlin, and if Bakhtin has the list, he’s on the run. Gray sits behind the Regent desk.
We don’t think he does. There’s no question he would have taken it straight to Moscow. Cc The list is still in Berlin.
Perceval is searching for it, but we want another pair of hands at the tiller as it were. C leans ever so slightly forward in his chair to commit importance to his words.
Most of the allied officers have been in Berlin for years.

SUPER: “EAST BERLIN, NOVEMBER 2, 1989” Perceval slams a empty shot glass of whiskey down on the We hear Public Enemy’s Chuck D coming through the SPEAKER with “Fight the Power.” Drunk East German youth fill the place. It’s a strange mix of punk, hip hop, and anti-East German establishment. Perceval takes some D-marks from a KID for a bottle of Ja Daniels and a old Penthouse magazine. Another East German hands him money, and Perceval hands over a pair of Levi's Perceval has a nice little side business in selling contraband. Cc (V.0.) With no embassy to watch over them, they play by their only rules. Perceval sees a clean-cut East German enter and sit at a quiet table near the bar.  12. This is SPYGLASS. He is the real reason Perceval is in the East. Perceval m across the room and joins him at the table. Perceval hand small brown bag of contraband (canned food, Jack Daniels women’s jeans) to Spyglass.
The Jordache jeans were not easy.
They are for my wife’s birthday.
Let me cut right to the bone. Where is the goddamn list?
Is this a joke?
No joke.
I gave it to Gascione last night.
Gascione never showed. Spyglass looks up at Perceval with consternation settling his brown eyes.
Why do you think I jumped the Wall, and I made contact with you?
I don’t know. I followed all the orders. Look, I was careful. I met Gascione in Friedrichshain. He took the list from me. Spyglass’'s eyes are filling with despair.
I did my part. I have risked everything.... You must to get me and my family across!
Calm down. Perceval studies Spyglass for a moment.  13.
Are you going to kill me?
I’ve thought about it... However, I can’t ignore the fact you are telling me the truth. Spyglass takes a breath as he controls his anxiety.
Did you make a copy of the list?
No... I memorized it.
The entire list? Spyglass nods. Suddenly, the front door of the club is ki in. We see the green-gray uniforms of the EAST GERMAN STA OFFICERS surge into the crowd.
Goddamn it. Perceval scans the room. An EAST GERMAN BARTENDER quickly motions to him.

Move! Perceval and Spyglass avoid the chaos of the room. The bartender pulls back a small service door to reveal a hallway. The bartender, Perceval, Spyglass, and several patrons ru down the hallway to the door leading outside. Perceval op the door to see two STASI OFFICERS standing directly in f of him.

(in German) You? Your papers! Now! Spyglass and the others are in the hallway, unseen to the Stasi. Perceval reaches into his pocket and pulls out a w leather wallet. He steps towards the Stasi and in the sam motion, throws the wallet into one officer’s face as a distraction. Perceval punches one Stasi in the throat and knees the other in the family jewels. Both drop to the al and writhe in pain.  14. Perceval looks back through the door, still open a few in as Spyglass and the others are witness to his burst of violence.
I'll be in contact. Perceval steps past the two Stasi on the ground and slowl jogs away down the alley and into the night.

It seems Berlin has its way with the younger generation. It’s infectious, an epidemic really. They’re all feral and have gone native. INT. CENTURY HOUSE - GRAY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Broughton exhales her Woodbine and stares at Gray and C through the smoke.

You have no family, no colleagues, no friends there. Cc No history to confuse your loyalties. You don’t even know Perceval. C stands and slowly walks towards the threshold of the of door. C pauses with his back to the room. Cc (CONT'D) When that bloody Wall comes crashing down, we don’t want to be under it. I want that list, Broughton. Bring it back home, and you'll find yourself at Buckingham for tea. C moves out the door, and Broughton looks back across the desk at Gray.

I recommended you for this. So, do try and look grateful. Gray hands Broughton the TS folder.  15. GRAY (CONT’D) I know, it’s short notice. H/WAR suggested you use Gladys Lloyd, as she was never compromised. Commit everything to memory and then burn it all. Gray points to a large metal “burn can” for documents in corner of the room.

A car will take you to your flat. Pack and then go straight to Heathrow. Remember, Lorraine, trust no one. Gray walks toward the office door. Broughton flips open t folder to a black-and-white photo of BER-1, David Perceva
What’s he like, sir? David Perceval.
Perceval carries a flashlight and takes a pull off a fift JD. He walks briskly and makes his way through a covert tunnel network towards West Berlin.
David Perceval is a royal pain in the ass. INT. CENTURY HOUSE - GRAY’S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS Gray stops and turns at his office door.

However, he is arguably one of the best damn spies to ever serve the Crown. My office is yours. Gray steps out of the office, and Broughton opens the TS folder in front of her. PRE-LAP on soundtrack: “One Thing Leads to Another” by Th Fixx.  16.

Broughton is in a window seat. We see a couple empty mini bottles of Stoli on the tray in front of her and hardcove copy of Trevanian’s “Shibumi”. Broughton looks out the wi at the bleak November sky.

Broughton walks off the Pan Am flight and towards the passport control kiosks. She hands the West German PASSPO OFFICER her UK passport. He looks at the passport photo a then to Broughton. He flips through the pages with scruti gives her another look and then stamps her passport and w her through. We follow Broughton into the uncluttered airport terminal loose crowd waits for the arriving international traveler From this crowd, a GENTLEMAN steps forward, all business, extends his hand.

Ms. Lloyd? Broughton slows to a stop. The Gentleman’s British accent good, perhaps too good. GENTLEMAN (CONT’D) Mr. Perceval was running late. He sent me to pick you up. Broughton scans the terminal then looks back to the Gentleman. GENTLEMAN (CONT’D) Checked bags?
No.
Please, follow me.
Broughton eyes her surroundings as they cross into a park lot. We see an attractive WOMAN turn from a phone booth, watch them, then methodically dial a number on the pay phone.  17.
A forest green BMW 2002 sedan is isolated at the end of t parking lot. The Gentleman and Broughton climb in.
The Gentleman pulls out of the airport parking lot and on the main route. They drive in silence. Broughton looks into her side mirror and notices a Saab 9 Turbo tailing them.
Well... it’s a remarkable time to be in Berlin.
That so? Broughton looks again to her mirror and sees the Saab is still there.
The music, nightlife and great restaurants.
You've got a suggestion?

For the beautiful people, go to the Palm for a drink. Broughton looks back to the mirror. The Saab speeds up be them and taps the BMW 2002 in a perfect PIT maneuver. Broughton quickly buckles her seat belt. The Gentleman is busy controlling the car to notice Broughton reach across depress the button to his seat belt. The BMW spins off th road, and Broughton braces for impact. The BMW slams into a metal guard rail. The WINDSHIELD SHATTERS, and the Gentleman is ejected onto the hood. Broughton relaxes and looks out at the bloody and moaning body of her driver. A figure drags the Gentleman off the and onto the frozen ground. We see Perceval look back thr the shattered glass at Broughton.
Welcome to Berlin.  18. Perceval stuffs a rag in the Gentlemen’s mouth and secure his mouth, ankles and hands with duct tape. Broughton unbuckles her seat belt and steps out of the BMW.
I could have handled him.
I have no doubt. Question is: What were you waiting for? Perceval drags the Gentleman across to his idling Saab. T boot is already open.
Who does he work for?

Perceval dumps the Gentlemen into the boot. The Gentleman starts to realize what is happening. Broughton unloads a right hand into his face, more as a fuck you to Perceval anything. The Gentleman’s body goes limp. Perceval shoots a look, impressive.
I am on the ground five minutes and get blown.
You’re not blown. Perceval slams the boot closed.
He knew my name.
Troubling.
And yours.

Not surprised. Broughton and Perceval move and get into the car.  19. INT./EXT. PERCEVAL’S SAAB - CONTINUOUS The inside of the car is littered with Wienerwald wrapper and empty beer cans. Perceval jams the Saab into gear and speeds away.
How would anyone know I was on that flight? Perceval turns with a peripheral smile.
Those are the kinds of questions that keep us up late at night.
We should message the home office and let them know what happened.
Christ and Mother Mary. London sent you to sort this mess out?
I just go where I am told.
Story of our lives. Checkpoint Charlie, by the way. Perceval points out the windshield.
I’m not here to collect postcards.
Ahhh... You’re all business under that lipstick. Broughton ignores the remark.
I was told you'd be briefed.

Your cover is civil service? Gladys Lloyd, Cambridge-educated lawyer sent by James Gascione’s family to return the body and effects of their now-deceased son, a British subject.  20. Perceval looks for a reaction but gets nothing from Broughton.
Just how in the hell the suits think that’s going to help find our damn list is beyond me. Picking up Gascione’s body won’t take much time.
I‘1l just have to be creative. Perceval points outside the car again.
Brandenburg Gate. My office is just there... I suppose HQ thinks there’s no point in replacing Gascione with the Wall coming down.
Seems improbable after twenty-eight years.

Everything is probable. And that assertion confirms to me you don’t know the first damn thing about this city, so don’t pretend you do. The tension builds within the car. Perceval SLAMS on the brakes and slides the car to stop. Perceval gets out of t car, opens the trunk, pulls the KGB driver out and drags onto the sidewalk. We see a sign the reads: “Embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic.” Perceval leans the KGB driver against the Soviet Embassy' wrought-iron gates. Within the compound several SOVIET GU start to move towards the gates.
What are you doing?
Sending my old friend Bremovych a message. Perceval stomps his foot across the driver’s face for goo measure.

INT. EAST BERLIN’S HOHENSCHONHAUSEN PRISON- NIGHT We see a man built like a Soviet T-10 battle tank. He wea gray Soviet translation of a Brooks Brothers suit and is business as he moves into the room. This is ALEKSANDER BREMOVYCH, KGB. A dozen STASI OFFICERS have six EAST GERMAN PUNK ROCKERS B-BOYZ from the underground night club lined up in their underwear against the wall. There is a wooden table in th center of the room and nothing more. Bremovych sets a car of Russian “Belomorkanal” cigarettes on the table.

(in German) You’re not free to go. You may never be free to go. Unless you tell me what I want to hear? Bremovych lights a filter-less Belomorkanal from a pack o twenty five. Four Stasi officers drag a young man over an SLAM him face down onto the table. Bremoyvch holds a smal B/W photo of Bakhtin. BREMOVYCH (CONT’D) (in German) Have you seen this man?
(in German) No. Bremoyvch nods and lays down another photo of Spyglass.
(in German) Last night at the club, did you see this man?

(in German) No. Bremoyvch takes a long drag on the filter-less cigarette then jams it into the young East German’s eye. The young howls in pain and buckles under his captor’s hands. Bremo lights another cigarette and holds up the carton for the of young men to witness.
(in German) If I must, I will use all of them to get the truth from you.  22. Bremovych turns back to the whimpering young East German.

INT. PERCEVAL’S SAAB —- CONTINUOUS Perceval and Broughton are driving through the streets of West Berlin. We see outside, a massive wall of graffiti-covered concre that divides East and West. Broughton
I didn’t travel as a QM, so I need you to supply me with a firearm.
This is Berlin, not Tombstone.
Gascione was assassinated, and I was just set up by the KGB.
If the KGB wants you dead, you’1l need more than good looks and a pistol. looks out the side window.
Turn left here and take me to my hotel.
They said you’d never been to Berlin. How in the hell do you know where your hotel is?
I can read a map, you chauvinistic sonofabitch. Perceval SLAMS on the brakes and pulls the car to a stop.
You may not be declared here by Her Majesty, but I am still the head of this goddamn station, and you'll respect me.  Broughton Broughton her small
A Patrick 23.
Respect is a two-way street, Mr. Perceval. Clearly, you don’t want me here. However, C himself gave me this job.
c is an arrogant lapdog and doesn’t know fuck all about the world past the edge of his desk! opens the door and steps out.
Good night, Mr. Perceval. crosses the hardscrabble street and walks towards hotel, never looking back.

Nagel print hangs on the wall. The room is equal parts Euro-chic and Miami Vice. We hear the RUNNING WATER from the bathroom. Broughton sits on the edge of the bed watching MTV news on a color Zenith.

The civil disobedience in East Berlin continues to build momentum. The disenfranchised youth leaders shout out their protests through the tear gas and water cannons. One eyewitness tells of police beating the peaceful demonstrators with batons. Broughton turns off the sound on the Zenith. She moves th hardcover of “Shibumi” onto the nightstand, picks up the rotary telephone, dials, and speaks.
Guten Abend. Ich bin Fraulen Lloyd, auf der Britische Botschaft Khan, Uh... Kann ich mit der Coroner Sprechen?
You are English? Why do you require the coroner?  24.
I’ve been sent to arrange the return of a British subject, recently dead... I’m told you have the body.

Nobody works tomorrow. It’s Sunday. Call Monday, in the morning. Auf Wiedersehen. Broughton hears a CLICK and sets the phone on its cradle. Broughton walks into the bathroom and turns off the cold water filling the chipped porcelain tub. She turns to a h dozen little ice buckets filled to the top and then dumps them into the bathtub. This is her daily ritual, the ice bath. Broughton switches off the bathroom light. The ZENITH is still PLAYING in the other room. She undresses in the fai light and steps into the freezing water without pause. Broughton sinks up to her nose with only her pale green e on the icy surface... then disappears below.

SUPER: “NOVEMBER 3, 1989” Broughton stands on the steps of a colorless apartment building and RINGS a call box BUZZER. Across the street, fifty feet away, is the graffiti-covered Berlin Wall snak through the neighborhood. INT. ATTACHE’S OFFICE - DAY Surveillance gear and monitors sit on a small table. Contraband is everywhere: LPs, Jack Daniels, cartons of L Strikes and Marlboro Reds. We hear the BUZZER, and Percev still in his clothes from last night, stirs and answers t call box.
Yeah.
Mr. Perceval? It’s Ms. Lloyd. You left a message at my hotel.  25.
I'll be right down. Perceval grabs his coat and moves towards the front door.

Broughton waits and watches a couple of children kick a soccer ball against the Wall. We see the same WOMAN from airport watching from a parked beige Mercedes 300D. After a few moments, Perceval exits his building.
Let’s take a walk. They start down the street, side by side.
About yesterday... in the car... the chauvinistic remarks. I shouldn’t have -- Broughton, without slowing her stride, interrupts.
Apology accepted. Perceval looks at Broughton and then clears the air betwe them with a simple nod.
It’s as cold as a witch’s tit on the dark side of the moon today.
I like the cold.
No wonder they kept sending you to Moscow. Broughton looks at Perceval.
Don’t act surprised. We both read each other’s file. Perceval stops at a street vendor selling currywurst from rolling cart. Perceval turns to Broughton.

Buy you breakfast?  26. Broughton doesn’t need to say no for Perceval to understa He buys two, and they walk through a broadstone archway. We see a sign that reads “TIERGARTEN PARK.” They continue on the crushed gravel path until stopping n to a frozen duck pond. Perceval throws small pieces of hi currywurst bun out onto the ice.
You shouldn’t feed them bread. It's bad for their digestion. A thin man wearing horn-rimmed glasses and a heavy winter topcoat approaches. It’s Emmett Kurzfeld.
She is right.
You damned Americans will back up anything in a skirt.
You must be Ms. Lloyd. I am Kurzfeld. Broughton extends her hand.
Pleased to meet you. Kurzfeld’s hand stays in the warmth of his pocket.
Kurzfeld here went to Princeton. Broughton slowly retracts her hand.
Kurzfeld thinks he knows everything... So you two should get along just fine.
I’ve been in Berlin almost as long as David... Nobody wants the list to fall into Soviet hands. Broughton looks to Perceval.  27.
What else have you shared with him?
Just women and scotch.
We watch out for one another. Broughton looks back to Kurzfeld.
I think Bakhtin is going to dump the list on the black market.
What makes you so sure?
If one of the Allies has it, we'd already know. If Moscow had it, there’s nothing we can do. So either Bakhtin puts it up for sale, or we'll never see it again.
She’s smart.
You only say that because you had that same idea. Kurzfeld turns to Perceval.
What’s the plan with Spyglass?
I haven't decided yet.
I should be going. Let me know if the company can help in any way. Kurzfeld nods towards Broughton.
Good day, Ms. Lloyd. Kurzfeld walks on alone through the park covered in rags snow and frozen grass.
Is there even a plan?  28.
Not yet, and if there was, I'd be damned if I'd share it with the Yanks.
The NAGRA III keeps recording. The ashtray on the table i filled with several crushed Woodbines. Gray and Kurzfeld across at Broughton.
So, how would you describe the situation on the ground those first couple of days?
Hostile.
With Perceval?
With everyone.
